Keeping Subscribers Engaged in Your Design System

bit.ly/meade-design-systems

Self Portrait with Straw Hat, 1887 by Vincent Van Gogh via VincentVanGogh.org

Tell a story here, Catherine. Van Gogh is an artist and nobody wants to buy his paintings. This is like design systems that we know are beautiful but no one wants to use. How do we do what Van Gogh couldn't, and get people to buy our paintings, er, design system?
“Giving positive feedback is an easy habit to adopt. You're already reading through the lines of code, looking for issues. It doesn't take much time to throw in a ‘Nice!’ or ‘Looks great!’ If you see something awesome, say it!”
- Bryan Braun
tiny.cc/foundry-braun
* This is really difficult for me. My Meyers-Briggs type is a INTJ. Famous INTJs are such lovable characters, like Minecroft from Sherlock, Walter White from Breaking Bad, and Littlefinger from Game of Thrones. We're not nice by default. We can be a little direct. * Sometimes positive feedback feels fake, but that's okay. It won't read that way. * I really like leading zeros on decimal points in CSS. In any language, I enjoy descriptive comments. I am always complimenting these things, and it may feel forced, but it is honest. * A few positive comments make a huge difference in overall tone of a review, whether you are speaking with developers, designers, or other team contributors.
“Giving positive feedback is an easy habit to adopt. You're already reading through the lines of code, looking for issues. It doesn't take much time to throw in a ‘Nice!’ or ‘Looks great!’ If you see something awesome, say it!”
- Bryan Braun

Thanks!

Catherine Meade
